My preference for the Draconian approach is based on
limited experience.  I had good results with it for my
Nim evolver.  There I was using floating point output
to select 1,2, or 3.  I took the nearest integer.  Any
result larger than 3.5 or smaller than .5 was an
illegal move.  Also illegal was choosing more than
remained, so if the remainder was only two, and 3 was
chosen, that's illegal.  I was able to evolve ANNs
that made only legal moves, and eventually played a
perfect game of Nim.

Later, I tried tic-tac-toe, using 9 outputs and using
the largest one for the move.  an illegal move was
when two or outputs were the same.  These were also
floating point, but could easily be tied at 1.0.
Early on, I found there were many illegal moves.  I
wound up selecting for legal move ability,
succesfully, but I never evolved any real players.

You guys may be right that a less draconian approach
would work better.  If I don't quickly succeed with my
first approach, I will try, try again. :)
